Key:
(I was in the middle of an evening walk
when I stopped myself in my tracks.)

(I looked up at the sky. Man, the stars were
mesmerizing tonight. But the sight made me
feel even lonelier.)

(In the silence of night, I opened my heavy
mouth.)
This is it, Tohka.

(Tohka was staring at the floor, but she
gasped as she looked up.)
What...? Why? WHY, SHIDO?!

(Her eyes flashed from bewilderment.
I watched as her lips trembled, and the
color began to drain from her face.)

(She must be in shock. If I could, I wanted
to hug and comfort her.)

(But all I could do was shake my head
weakly.)

I hope you understand. You're not a child,
anymore.
NO! I don't want to!

I cannot bear the thought of us breaking
apart!

(Her anguished cries pierced through me.
I gritted my teeth.)
I don't want to break up either, but...!

(I cut myself off, knowing there wasn't
anything else to say. Not in one breath.)
(The cruel truth. It was impossible to say.)

Please. Don't, Shido. I do not wish to hear it!
I would rather hear nothing at all!
No. Plugging your ears won't change anything.

(My throat croaked, squeezing the last
word out of my mouth.)
This is the point of no return!
(Tohka tightly gripped my shirt.)

(Her hand trembled, her eyes shaking from
fury, fighting back tears.)

(I... I bit my lips once again. I felt helpless,
but Tohka finally spoke up.)
Shido, after all we have been through...
(Tohka's eyes glimmered like a warm hearth.)

Hey, Shido. Do you remember? When we went
shopping for winter clothes?
Yes, I do...
You bought me a scarf and shoes.
Right. They looked lovely on you.
I heard you were reprimanded for that.

Yeah. Because of that, I had to buy fewer
ingredients for dinner, and Kotori yelled
at me.

(The thought of it sends a shiver down my
spine. Our meal was so sparse that Kotori
treated me with sub-zero contempt.)
For me, it was all worth it! I made you happy!

(I balled my hand into a fist, and shook
it away from her.)
Shido...! You said you cared about me...!

(Tohka covered her mouth, trying to resist
the urge to cry.)

(Oh. Tohka knows my pain. She's trying to
heal the wounds my heart has endured. This
alone was enough.)
(I shared a warm smile with her.)

Hey, Tohka. Remember when we went to
karaoke? We held the mic together.
Yes. We performed a duet with one mic.

So many cherished memories. I remember
them like they were yesterday.
We went several times afterward.
Yeah. I still love your singing voice, Tohka.

You flatter me, but it came from plenty of
practice, you know?

I memorized so many of the songs you told
me you liked. Hopefully one day, I can show
you.
Then, I will perform inside of a grand arena!
Haha. An arena concert, huh...?)

(An unattainable dream. I fight the urge
to laugh at its absurdity.)

(But I won't laugh at her. I would never
laugh at Tohka.)

I can't wait. You know I'll be there to watch
you.

(Suddenly, something hot slid down my
throat, choking me up. I cough, and drop
to my knees.)
Rgh! *cough, cough*!
Shido! Are you okay?!
(Tohka rubbed my back.)

(I huffed in pain, breathily describing a
scene to Tohka.)

Tohka, you also like playing with animals,
right? I even thought if I had bought a dog,
every day could've been an adventure.

A white house along the beach, with a big
yard. You're running around, chasing the
dog on the lawn.

(Another dream left unfulfilled. I'm sure
it would've made a funny story, but I know
it would never happen.)

(Tohka laughing from joy, cuddling up next
to her precious dog. A sight I never would
have tired of seeing.)

(A memory... paired with the sight of Tohka,
sitting tearfully before me. Which is the
dream? Which is reality?)
(I don't even know anymore.)

Me too. I wish to adopt a dog with you.
We can pet its fur, and teach it new tricks.

(My throat tightened. I fought the urge to
spit up. No, there's something I still need
to tell Tohka...!)

(My vision blurred, my eyes hot from tears.
Damn it...! I can't see!)

(Don't...let me see Tohka's face... At least,
not until the very end...)
Tohka...
Shido...

Please, understand. I don't... I don't want things
to end this way, either.
But... I have to.

(The time has come to make a decision.
I stood up, and took a deep breath.)

(I put my hand on Tohka's thin shoulder.
Her face was so gentle, round but soft.)
(I looked into her teary, crystal eyes.)
I can't be with you anymore.

(The words wretched out of my mouth
like blood.)
So, I have to say good-bye, Tohka.
Wh-What...?

(The color left Tohka's eyes, overshadowed
by a thick, burgeoning mist.)
(The air froze, much like Tohka's heart.)
(She became pale, and her voice shook.)
Do you really have to...?
I do.
You really, really have to?
I really, really have to!
But do you really, really, really have to?!
I REALLY REALLY REALLY HAVE TO!

Don't give me that look, Tohka! Don't
look at me that way!

(Through gritted teeth, I averted my gaze
away from Tohka. Try as I might, I couldn't.)

(Tohka looked like a woman, lost. She clutched
the sleeve of my shirt, refusing to let go, as if
it would cost her life.)
No. I would do anything not to leave you...
Shido, I want to be with you...!
Shido.
Tohka.
(We spoke each other's names.)
Shido!
Tohka!
(We spread our arms.)
SHIDOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!
TOOOOOOOHKAAAAA!

(We didn't care who saw or heard us.
We screamed as loud as lungs would let
us, and we engaged in tender embrace.)

Hey, like I said, this as far as I can see you
off.

You have school tomorrow, so you need to
go home.
And I need to go home, too.

I need to do homework, and prepare tomorrow's
lunch. You understand, don't you?
*gulp*...
Don't think about food right now.

You live right next to me, so when you go
outside, we'll be there.
That's why we must part here.
You understand, right? Right?
(Tohka pouted, so I repeated myself.)

(How many times have we had this talk?
I'm tired of it by now.)
Tohka, where's my answer?
...*whimper*.
There's no point whimpering. No.
BOOO.
No pouting, either.
GRRR!
JUST TALK!
(Tohka shifted her eyes.)
I know. I know, but...

(Her body language was that of a petulant
child's.)
I DO NOT WANT TO!
What are you, a child...?

(In her frustration, Tohka gripped me tighter.
My sleeves were almost entirely wrinkled.)

(This is how Tohka gets whenever we part.
She is so reluctant to do so that she has to
partake in melodrama to get through it.)

(It could be my fault too. Since we are the
type to revel in being a lovey-dovey couple.)

How heartless can you be, to say good-bye
to me so easily, Shido?

(Finally, she turns to face me, and asks me
directly.)

Why? That's a normal thing to say. When you
go home, you say good-bye.

Just like when you say good-bye to your
classmates at school.
I say, "See you tomorrow."
There's no difference...

(Nevertheless, Tohka was dissatisfied with
my answer.)

I cannot bring myself to say good-bye so
easily.

(Tohka wore a grim expression. More serious
than I had ever seen her.)

Because good-bye means you will never see
each other again, right?

There is a finality to it. If I say good-bye, then
I cannot see you until the next day.
I do not like it...

I do not want to go a single day or night
without you. In truth, the thought of not
seeing you is torture. Utter despair.
Good-bye is a lonesome greeting. Am I wrong?
Hmm...

(Her reasoning was unexpectedly sound.
I scratched my cheek.)

(In truth, I found it touching that she
thought so highly of me.)

I mean, I'm lonely too. If I could be with you
all the time, I would be.
...Really?

Of course. That's why I can't fault you for
hating to say good-bye.

Then, when why do you inflict this cruelty
upon me by saying good-bye...?

Because I have faith that we will see each
other tomorrow, too.
(Tohka blinked twice in quick succession.)

I can see you tomorrow, and the day after.
It's not something you need to worry about.

We can have dinner again tomorrow, then go
on another date.
That's why... I say good-bye.
Can I see you tomorrow? Is that a certainty?

Yes, it is certain. I want to see you, Tohka.
Do you not feel the same?

Of course not! I want to see you tomorrow,
and the following day! I never wish to be apart!

Right? Then we can see each other again
tomorrow.
Good-bye means, "I'll see you again," too.

I see. So even we say good-bye, then we
will reunite soon.

No... When I say good-bye, it is a reminder
that I get to be with you again!

If I think of it in those terms, I can never be
afraid of good-bye again! Not a bad idea!

I can see you tomorrow, and the following
day. That is what you're promising, right
Shido?

I want to see you many times. A hundred
times. A thousand times!
(Her smile stretched from ear to ear.)

(Getting to see me. To Tohka, that is the
greatest pleasure in the world.)

(With that, she has enough hope to carry
on to the next day.)

(That is how precious our time is to her.
How could that not make me happy?)
I can see you tomorrow, right Shido?
Of course.
And the day after, too?

Tomorrow, the following day, the day after that,
and the day after that. We will say good-bye and
reunite until the end of time.
I see. Then I will be okay!
(The brightness returned to Tohka's voice.)

(This was the true Tohka. I don't like the
thought of her being gloomy.)
Then I'll see you tomorrow, Tohka.
Okay! See you tomorrow, Shido!

(We said good-bye and waved, but it is not
a permanent separation.)
Let's meet again tomorrow, Tohka.

Okay, Shido. Tomorrow, the following day.
Good-bye is never forever.
Right!

(We reunite, we talk, we date. Repeating
the cycle that follows each good-bye.)

(Even so, we'll never be apart. So long
as we promise to be in each other's lives.)
Shido, good-bye!

(Good-bye doesn't have to mean separation.
It is a precursor to the beauty of a reunion,
when your beloved re-enters your life.)
